A new triazine-thiophene based porous organic polymer as efficient catalyst for the synthesis of chromenes via multicomponent coupling and catalyst support for facile synthesis of HMF from carbohydrates Sabuj Kanti Das 1 Sauvik Chatterjee 1 Sujan Mondal Asim Bhaumik ⁎ School of Materials Sciences, Indian Association for the Cultivation of Science, Kolkata, 700032, India School of Materials Sciences Indian Association for the Cultivation of Science Kolkata 700032 India School of Materials Sciences, Indian Association for the Cultivation of Science, Kolkata - 700032, India ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 These authors contribute equally. Graphical abstract N-rich triazine-thiophene based microporous polymer TrzDBTH has been synthesized by Friedel-Craft alkylation reaction and it showed high catalytic activity for the multicomponent reaction for the synthesis of chromenes. Upon sulfonation this porous polymer showed high catalytic efficiency for the synthesis of HMF from carbohydrates. Functionalized porous organic polymers are very demanding and promising material in heterogeneous catalysis due to their convenience in synthesis and versatility in framework composition. Further, owing to the tunable porosity, high specific surface area, ease of functionalization and chemical stability, this class of porous polymers have huge potential to be employed both as catalysis and catalyst support. Herein, we report N-rich triazine-thiophene based microporous polymer TrzDBTH through the Friedel-Craft alkylation reaction of tripodal building block 2,4,6-tris[4-(bromomethyl)phenyl]-1,3,5-triazine with dibenzothiophene (DBTH) and used it as a heterogeneous base catalyst for one-pot synthesis of biologically important chromene derivatives. Further, sulfonation to this TrzDBTH material yielded sulfonated hyper-crosslinked porous polymer namely STrzDBTH, which can be used as solid acid catalyst for the synthesis of valuable chemical intermediate 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) from different biomass derived carbohydrates. As a base catalyst, TrzDBTH provides chromene yields from 88 to 93% and its sulfonated derivative STrzDBTH provides the HMF yields from 57 to 97% for different carbohydrate substrates. Both the materials displayed high recycling efficiencies for several catalytic cycles. Thus, these triazine-thiophene based porous organic polymers offer very economical, scalable and recyclable routes for the synthesis chromene derivatives and HMF. Keywords Chromene derivatives HMF synthesis Porous organic polymers Sulfonation Surface acidic and basic sites Introduction Porous organic materials [1–4] have recently been emerged as a fascinating material, especially in the context of their utility in gas storage and heterogeneous catalyst [5,6]. These materials can be synthesized through the polycondensation of organic building blocks consisting of aromatic or aliphatic backbone and they possesses high specific surface area and porosity in nanoscale dimensions [7]. In recent time different classes of porous organic materials have been synthesized viz. covalent organic frameworks (COFs) [8], conjugate microporous polymers (CMPs) [9], porous polymeric networks (PPNs) [10], porous aromatic frameworks (PAFs) [11], covalent triazine framework (CTFs) [12], hyper-cross-linked organic polymer (HCP) [13] etc. High accessible surface area of porous organic materials are particularly helpful in carrying out a wide range of catalytic reactions using these materials [14–17]. Syntheses of these materials are quite economical and involve less number of steps than the related microporous and mesoporous materials synthesized through templating pathways [18]. Owing to robust nature and existence of framework covalent bonds, these materials can work for a wide temperature range in catalysis and energy applications together with excellent reusability. Further, organic moieties present in the porous organic polymers (POPs) can be functionalized with -SO3H groups at its surface [19] and due to high acidity, resulting materials can be explored for the conversion of biomass including carbohydrates to platform chemicals like 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) or related biofuel products [20–22]. One-pot multicomponent reactions (MCR) [23] are very demanding due to their atom economy and energy efficiency of the processes. The simplicity of the reaction along with selective formation of new CO, CN, CC [24] bonds have made this synthetic route highly attractive for the synthesis of heterocyclic organic compound. Benzopyrans [25], benzoxanthene [26], benzochromene [27] and various other heterocyclic molecules that show wide range of biological and pharmaceutical activity can be synthesized using one-pot MCR. Among these includes 2-amino-4H-chromene derivatives, which are highly demanding chemicals for biological applications. These derivatives have been successfully utilized as building blocks of AChE, BuChE and MK2-inhibitor [28], antimicrobial [29], anti-cancer therapeutic [27], antioxidant [30], antitumor molecules/drugs [31] and in-vitro studies of anti-bacterial agents [32]. These are conventionally synthesized using base catalyst such as DBU [33], piperazine [34], NaOH [35], Et3N [36], potassium phthalimide [37], K2CO3 [38], MgO [39] etc. These processes are very efficient giving high yields of chromene derivatives, but the sole disadvantage with this route is the catalysts are homogeneous in nature. Thus, it involves extra steps and hazardous organic volatile solvents to remove the catalyst from the reaction mixture and hence the catalyst can’t be recycled. The use of heterogeneous catalyst alleviates this ordeal as it can be removed simply using filtration technique and can be reemployed for multiple reaction cycles. Thus, POPs having basic centers or basic functionalization have huge scope to be explored in this context as heterogeneous catalyst. Herein, we report a new triazine-thiophene based POP TrzDBTH (Scheme 1 ), thoroughly characterized it to understand its framework/bonding, structural stability, basicity and surface area, and employed as a base catalyst for the one-pot MCR for the synthesis of 2-amino-4H-chromene derivatives under microwave heating conditions (Scheme 2 ). When we sulfonated the aromatic rings of the TrzDBTH with chlorosulfonic acid it resulted a new acidic catalyst STrzDBTH with -SO3H rich porous surface. This solid catalyst is very robust in nature and displayed total acid strength of 2.41 mmol g−1 owing to presence of abundant -SO3H groups. STrzDBTH has been employed as solid acid catalyst for the synthesis of HMF from different carbohydrates. HMF is recognized as one of the ten most demanding energy chemicals by US department of energy [40]. Fructose to HMF conversion is a very much challenging reaction under the present industrial scenario since the source is green and can be obtained from sugarcane extract. HMF and its derivatives not only serve as biofuel source [41], they are also exploited as monomer unit for several polymer, plastic [42], pharmaceutical, dye additives and related fine chemicals. HMF derivative dimethylfuran and its ethers e.g. methoxymethylfurfural (MMF) and ethoxymethylfurfural (EMF) are used in as additives to fuel, whereas 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) [43] and tetrahydrofuran-dimethaol (THFDM) may serve as building blocks for the production of high performance polyurethane, polyesters, adhesives and resins. In this work we have explored the triazine-thiophene based porous organic polymer as base catalyst for chromene synthesis as well as catalyst support for the transformation of natural sugar resources to HMF in a single step. Experimental section Chemicals 4-(Bromomethyl)benzonitrile and dibenzothiophene were procured from Sigma Aldrich, India. Anhydrous AlCl3 and solvents were received from E-Merck, India. Triflic acid was purchased from Spectrochem, India. All chemicals were used as purchased. Material characterizations 1H and 13C NMR were obtained using Bruker AVANCE III-400 MHz spectrometer. Elemental analysis like carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen and sulphur contents of TrzDBTH was determined by Perkin Elmer 2400 Series II CHN analyzer. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectral data were taken by using Perkin-Elmer Spectrum 100 spectrophotometer. Wide-angle powder X-Ray diffraction patterns of two materials were collected with a Bruker AXS D8 Advanced SWAX diffractometer using Cu Kα (λ = 0.15406 nm) radiation. A 500 MHz Bruker Avance II spectrometer was used to collected the 13C cross-polarization magic angle spinning (CP-MAS) NMR spectrum at a mass frequency of 8 kHz. Volumetric nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherm, Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface area and porosity analysis were carried out using Autosorb 1-C (Quantachrome Instruments, USA) at 77 K. Prior to gas adsorption measurement the powdered materials were activated in vacuum at 140 °C for about 12 h. Pore-size distributions were calculated from the adsorption/desorption isotherms by using non-local density functional theorem (NLDFT). Thermo gravimetry analysis (TGA) of TrzDBTH and STrzDBTH were analyzed in a thermal analyzer TA-SDT Q-600. High resolution transmission electron microscopic (HRTEM) images of the TrzDBTH and STrzDBTH materials before and after catalysis were obtained using a JEOL JEM 2010 transmission electron microscope. The samples for HRTEM analysis were prepared by drop casting of a colloidal solution onto the carbon-coated copper grids followed by drying under high vacuum. From a Hitachi S-5200 field-emission scanning electron microscope, all FESEM images of the materials were taken for morphological study. The multiplicities of 1H NMR spectra were represented as s (singlet), d (doublet), t (triplet), m (multiplet) and br (broad). The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was taken from an Omicron Nanotechnology XPS 0571 spectrometer. The surface acidity and basicity of TrzDBTH and STrzDBTH was determined using CO2-TPD and NH3-TPD analysis, respectively by using the Micromeritics ChemiSorb 2720 temperature programmed desorption apparatus fitted with a thermal conductivity detector. Synthetic procedure of 2,4,6-tris[4-(bromomethyl) phenyl]-1,3,5-triazine 2,4,6-Tris[4-(bromomethyl)phenyl]-1,3,5-triazine was synthesized following a previously reported procedure [44]. In a dry 100 ml round-bottom flask, 4-bromomethyl-benzonitrile (5 g, 25.5 mmol) was taken and kept it on ice bath. Then triflic acid (5 mL) was added slowly. The mixture was then allowed to stir for 18 h under N2 atmosphere. The resulting yellow mixture was poured into 100 ml of ice cold water and neutralized with concentrated ammonium hydroxide. The white coloured precipitate was filtered off and washed with plenty of water followed by little amount of acetone. The solid compound was dried in an oven at 60 °C to obtained constant weight. Finally 4.3 g (yield: 86%) of pure product were obtained. 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ = 8.7 (d, 6 H), 7.6 (d, 6 H), 4.6 (s, 6 H) ppm; 13C NMR (CDCl3, 100 MHz): δ = 33, 129, 136, 142, 171 ppm. Synthesis of TrzDBTH In a typical synthesis a 50 ml RB was first charged with dibenzothiophene (0.276 g, 1.5 mmol), 2,4,6-tris[4-(bromomethyl)phenyl]-1,3,5-triazine (1.172 g, 2 mmol) and anhydrous dichloroethane (DCE). Then 0.85 g of anhydrous AlCl3 was added to that followed by the stirring at room temperature for 3 h. It was then stirred for 20 h at 70 °C maintaining inert atmosphere. The precipitate was filtered and washed successively with plenty of THF and MeOH using a soxhlet apparatus. The material was then washed with acetone. Finally, the dark yellow coloured TrzDBTH was collected and dried in vacuum for overnight. The obtained weight of the dry material was 1.13 g. Synthesis of STrzDBTH Following a reported synthesis procedure [6] STrzDBTH was synthesized via sulphonation of TrzDBTH. In a typical synthesis, TrzDBTH (300 mg) and 20 ml DCE were taken in a 50 ml RB. 3 ml chlorosulphonic acid in 5 ml DCE was added dropwise into the mixture under stirring at 0 °C temperature and then the final mixture was allowed to stir for 80 h. Then the reaction mixture was poured into 250 ml of ice-cold water. Then the content was filtered off and thoroughly washed with plenty of water, followed by MeOH, THF, acetone and finally dried under vacuum at 90 °C to afford black coloured sulphonated material STrzDBTH and this is employed as the heterogeneous solid acid catalyst. Optimization of HMF yields 135 mg (0.75 mmol) of D-fructose was taken in 6 ml dimethyl sulfoxide and 45 mg STrzDBTH catalyst was added to it. Then the reaction mixture heated in a microwave reactor at 140 ⁰C for 20 min. The mixture was then extracted using diethyl ether and purified using column chromatography with petroleum ether and ethyl acetate (20:1) to get yellow oil like liquid. The yield was 96.2 wt% (91 mg) under this optimized condition. For D-glucose the observed yield was 61.3 wt% (58 mg). Isolated yields calculated based on the pure HMF amounts (wt%) derived from D-fructose, D-glucose and sucrose are provided in Table 3. The yields of HMF was also derived from the UV–vis spectra by measuring the absorbance of the aliquots of the reaction mixtures at 284 nm (molar extinction coefficient ε = 1.66 × 104 M−1 cm−1) and 1H NMR spectra. Results and discussion We have carried out the Friedel-Craft alkylation reaction between triazine-based tripodal building block 2,4,6-tris[4-(bromomethyl)phenyl]-1,3,5-triazine (Trz-3PhCH2Br) and dibenzothiophene (DBTH) in the presence of anhydrous AlCl3 as Lewis acid catalyst. The resulting microporous brown colored polymer TrzDBTH was used as a base catalyst for the synthesis of 2-amino-4H-chromene derivatives, whereas the sulfonated product STrzDBTH with free –SO3H groups has been employed as solid acid catalyst for the synthesis of HMF from carbohydrates. Spectroscopic analysis The successful synthesis of POP framework and various bonds present in the material was confirmed by FTIR analysis. FTIR spectra shown in Fig. 1 displayed strong peaks at 1507 and 1509 cm−1, which could be attributed to the presence of triazine units in the TrzDBTH and STrzDBTH, respectively [44]. The peaks at 1352 and 1361 cm−1 observed for TrzDBTH and STrzDBTH materials indicated the presence of stretching vibrations of the triazine ring [12]. The band at 1036 cm−1 and 1178 cm−1 could be assigned for the asymmetric stretching modes of SO bonds, which confirmed the successful grafting of –SO3H groups at the surface of TrzDBTH network [6]. In addition, 13C cross polarization magic angle spinning (CP-MAS) NMR spectrum (Fig. 2 ) of porous network (TrzDBTH) showed a broad peak at ˜168 ppm [6] as a characteristic peak for sp2 carbon atom of triazine ring [45]. The peaks near 151 and 109 ppm for TrzDBTH could be assigned to the two thiophenic carbon atoms, respectively at the (8) and (9) positions. The various carbons come from dibenzothiophenic unit and the phenyl attached to triazine unit (2, 3, 4, 7, 10 and 11), are responsible for the intense peak at 128 ppm. NMR signal was appeared at 48 ppm, which indicated the presence of the ethylene group in the polymer network. Surface area and porosity measurement To find out the porosity and specific surface areas, N2 adsorption-desorption analysis has been carried out for the activated powder samples of TrzDBTH and STrzDBTH at 77 K (Fig. 3 ). This experiment revealed TrzDBTH has very high degree of porosity. The nature of N2 sorption isotherm observed for TrzDBTH can be classified as a mixture of type I (at low P/P0) and type IV (at intermediate region of P/P0). The pore size distributions were calculated by using non-local density function theory (NLDFT), which revealed that TrzDBTH is microporous in nature with peak pore diameter of 1.6 nm. The specific surface area was calculated in the partial pressure (P/P0) range of N2 between 0.01 to 0.2 and the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of TrzDBTH was found to be 821 m2 g−1. Upon sulfonation, however the BET surface area for STrzDBTH has been reduced to 374 m2 g−1 with an average pore width of ca. 1.5 nm. Reduction of surface area as well as the pore width in STrzDBTH could be attributed to the presence of abundant -SO3H groups at its surface. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm for STrzDBTH also showed a mixture of type I and type IV isotherms, which indicated the presence of large micropores in STrzDBTH. CO2 gas adsorption study The microporous hypercrosslinked polymer TrzDBTH bearing N-sites of the triazine moiety together with high BET surface area are highly desirable for its potential in CO2 capture [46]. Thus, we have measured the quantitative CO2 uptake capacity of the TrzDBTH material at 273 and 298 K up to 1 bar pressure (Fig. 4 ). Up to 1.0 bar pressure TrzBDTH material showed 4.1 and 2.4 mmol reversible CO2 uptakes at 273 and 298 K, respectively. High CO2 uptakes at atmospheric pressure over TrzDBTH suggested considerable surface basicity of this POP material and this has motivated us to carry out the base catalysed MCR for the synthesis of chromene derivatives. Microstructural analysis Morphological and nanostructural analysis of TrzDBTH and STrzDBTH have been carried out by using high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) analysis (Fig. 5 ). From FE-SEM images of TrzDBTH (Fig. 5a) and STrzDBTH (Fig. 5b), it is quite evident that both the materials are composed of submicron size spherical particles with average particle size of 40–50 nm. The HRTEM images of TrzDBTH (Fig. 5c) and STrzDBTH (Fig. 5d) also support the similar type of morphology of both the porous organic materials. The HRTEM images of two recycled catalysts after their respective 5th consecutive reaction cycles are shown in Fig. S1. The HRTEM images of recycled catalysts confirmed the spherical morphology along with retention of particle size as that of the POP material before catalysis. This result suggested good structural stability of these porous polymers. PXRD, thermogravimetric, XPS and elemental analysis To check crystalline or amorphous nature of the materials, PXRD analysis has been performed with both the materials from 2θ value 5 to 50 degrees (Fig. S2). Appearance of a broad peak within 10–30° for both materials confirm the amorphous nature of the TrzDBTH and STrzDBTH materials [46]. We have carried out the thermogravimetric analysis of both the organic polymers in the temperature range 25 to 590 °C (Fig. S3) to understand their thermal stability. As seen from Fig. S3, the organic framework of the TrzDBTH material is thermally stable up to 315 °C. The TGA plot of sulfonic group modified material showed three step weight losses in which first weight loss could be attributed to the evaporation of surface absorbed moisture, second weight loss is assigned for the loss of SO3H functionality and final weight loss is ascribed due to the burning of the organic framework. XPS analysis has been conducted for the STrzDBTH (Fig. 6 ) to understand the type of bonding and connectivity of the sulfur atoms. As seen from this figure that there are two types of signals with binding energy (BE) at 163 and 168 eV for S2p. These BE correspond to the presence of S in thiophene moiety and S in -SO3H functionality, respectively [46,47]. Elemental analysis has been performed to analyze the composition of POPs along with presence of hetero atoms like N and S. C, H, N and S contents of these materials are: 81.14, 4.39, 6.74 and 7.74 for TrzDBTH and 56.24, 2.98, 4.46 and 14.17% for STrzDBTH, respectively. This result agrees well with the theoretical composition of TrzDBTH and STrzDBTH building units (Scheme 1). Basicity and acidity measurement We have estimated basicity and acidity of TrzDBTH and STrzDBTH materials through temperature programmed desorption (TPD) analysis of CO2 and NH3, respectively. These TPD analyses have been carried out in the temperature range of 25–200 °C for TrzDBTH and 25–180 °C for STrzDBTH. In case of TrzDBTH material a peak with desorption maxima at 58 °C was observed (Fig. 7 B), whereas single broad peak with desorption maxima at 77 °C was observed for the acid catalyst STrzDBTH (Fig. 7A). The measured Lewis basicity of TrzDBTH from CO2-TPD profile was 0.36 mmol g−1, which indicated the presence of mild surface basicity in this porous polymer material [48]. In contrast, the acidity of the STrzDBTH was 2.41 mmol g−1 which is mainly contributed due to the presence of the presence of abundant surface -SO3H groups. The acidity and basicity for STrzDBTH and TrzDBTH respectively was estimated with acid-base titration method (ESI Section 1). The total acidity of STrzDBTH was found to be 2.41 mmol g−1 and total basicity of TrzDBTH was found 0.321 mmol g−1, which agrees well with the TPD analyses. Catalysis Synthesis of 2-amino-4H-chromene derivatives Since TrzDBTH has basic sites due to the framework N-atoms with total basicity of ca. 0.32 mmol g−1 (as measured by acid-base titration) together with high BET surface area we have attempted to synthesize 2-amino-4H-chromene derivatives via one-pot multicomponent coupling reaction using different aromatic aldehydes, malononitrile and resorcinol. Elinson et al. have reported electocatalytic synthesis of 2-amino-4H-chromene [49] from salicyldehyde bearing both electron donating and electron-withdrawing moieties as well as CH acids. However, this multicomponent reaction can proceed usually both in the presence of acid and base catalysts. Homogeneous base catalysts viz. Na2CO3, NaHCO3 etc. are employed for this reaction with 100% and 89% yields, respectively [50]. But the reaction involve high temperature, longer reaction time together with no recyclability. We have previously reported the synthesis of 2-amino-4H-chromene by using porous organic polymers bearing basic N-sites [37]. To optimize the reaction conditions for the MCR with TrzDBTH we took malononitrile, benzaldehyde and resorcinol with water as green solvent and TrzDBTH as heterogeneous catalyst under microwave irradiation. The reaction gave highest yield (93%) within 20 min reaction time, increasing the reaction time did not give any better result. In-spite of low basic strength, TrzDBTH showed comparatively good catalytic activity (Table 1 ) with those reported in literature and this is reflected in its high turnover numbers (TONs). The higher surface area makes the active sites more accessible, leading to faster reaction rate, which in turn leads to higher TON. On the other hand, TPOP-2 has higher basicity but lower BET surface area, hence the TON is comparatively low in this case. TFMO-1 [51], which has higher surface area than that of TPOP-2 but lower than TrzDBTH gives an intermediate TON value for this particular set of reactions. The reaction was also carried out in conventional round-bottom flask and condenser with oil bath heating, but the reaction time ranged between 6–8 h for obtaining comparable yields. The reaction was optimized with respect to temperature, time and amount of catalyst used in the reaction. The reaction showed no improvement with respect to yield beyond 100 °C temperature (Table 2 ). The yields were 73 and 58%, respectively when the reactions were carried out at 80 and 50 °C. When the reaction was carried out at 140 °C the yield decreased to 82%. This could be attributed due to the decomposition of some product or intermediates. In order to find the effect of solvent the reaction was carried out with several solvents. However, water was found to be the most suitable solvent with highest yield (93%), followed by ethanol, which gave 79% yield of the product for the representative reaction between benzaldehyde, malononitrile and resorcinol. Further, when this MCR was carried out under solvent-free conditions it showed good chromene yield (ca. 85%). Whereas solvents like acetonitrile, 1,4-dioxane, dimethyl formamide gave significantly lower yield. The catalytic reaction pathway for this MCR over TrzDBTH is shown in the Scheme 2. This condensation reaction between the three components could not proceed when we tried to carry out the reaction without any catalyst. The result showed the catalyst quite compatible to do this condensation with a wide range of substituted benzaldehydes. The controlled experiments reported previously by our group [37] suggest there were 39–45% yields when homogeneous basic catalysts viz. piperazine, Ca(OH)2, pyridine, hexylamine etc. are used to perform this reaction under classical oil-bath heating conditions. When we did the same set of experiments under microwave conditions using 4-nitrobenzaldehyde as the aromatic aldehyde as substrate we got yield 25–31 % (Table 2). The amount of the catalyst was gradually increased during the reaction. Beyond 0.1 wt % loading of the catalyst in the reaction mixture the yield did not increase considerably upon increasing the amount of catalyst. The yield found to be 93%, which is quite good considering the previously reported heterogeneous catalysts [52]. The versatility of the catalyst was checked by using different aldehyde derivatives (Table 1) and the yield in each case found to be quite good. To check the reusability the catalyst the reaction between malononitrile, benzaldehyde and resorcinol was carried out under optimized reaction conditions. The catalyst was recovered by filtration and washed several times, activated at 120 °C before carrying out the next catalytic cycle. Until 5th cycle the catalyst did not show any loss in its catalytic activity. In the successive cycles the catalytic efficiency of TrzDBTH dropped very slightly (Fig. S4), suggesting future scope of this porous polymer in this multicomponent reaction. Conversion of carbohydrates to Hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) Sulfonated porous polymer STrzDBTH with high surface acidity was exploited for the conversion of carbohydrate to 5-hydroxymethylfurfural. The conversion is conventionally executed using concentrated sulfuric acid and the reaction was essentially a multistep reaction giving undesired byproducts like formic acid, levulinic acid etc. [53]. Here we have used STrzDBTH as solid acid catalyst to obtain HMF in a single step and short reaction time with high yield. The HMF conversions were measured with available and cheaper raw carbohydrate sources like fructose, sucrose and glucose. The activity of the sulfonated STrzDBTH catalyst was checked and optimized to obtain highest yield of HMF. We began our preliminary catalysis with fructose as substrate and 10 mg of STrzDBTH in DMSO under microwave irradiation. The temperature for the optimized reaction was found to be 140 ⁰C to obtain the best HMF yield (97%). Detailed catalytic results are presented in Table 3. To determine the optimum catalyst amount in this reaction, the model reaction was re-performed with different catalyst loadings at 140 °C for 20 min. When the reaction was carried out without catalyst we achieved negligible yield of HMF. As seen from Fig. 8 , for a fixed amount of fructose (45 mg) the yields of HMF gradually increased (ca. 45% to 96.2%, based on isolated yield in wt%) with the increase in STrzDBTH dose from 2 to 20 mg. When the catalyst loading was increased beyond 15 mg, no significant improvement in product yield observed. The fructose conversion was further tested to evaluate the optimum product yield by varying the reaction time from 5 to 30 min. With an increase of reaction time product yield increased primarily till 20 min, but at longer reaction times drop in the reaction yield was observed. The conversion of sugar is decreased at longer time, possibly due to the degradation of HMF to organic acids, humins etc. [49,53–56]. The yields of the HMF calculated by using 1H NMR (Fig. S5) of pure product with respect to mesitylene as reference as well as from UV–vis spectra (Table S1) agrees very well with the isolated product yields. The TON for the optimized reaction with D-fructose was found to be 6.2, which is quite high and comparable to the catalyst reported earlier by our group. [5] The high TON could be attributed to high BET surface area of STrzDBTH, which in turn allows more number of active sites to participate in the reaction. The heterogeneous nature of the STrzDBTH catalyst has been confirmed through hot-filtration test. Our experimental data showed that there is no leaching of functionalized -SO3H groups took place during the course of sugar hydrolysis. The recyclability of this catalyst was tested for this reaction and a consistent performance was observed as shown for the consecutive five reaction cycles (Fig. S6). For carrying out the recycling experiment, we have filtered the catalyst from the reaction mixture and washed it repeatedly with ethyl acetate and then methanol followed by drying in air oven for overnight at 100 °C, before carrying out the next reaction cycle. Conclusions A new triazine-thiophene functionalized microporous polymer TrzDBTH has been synthesized by a simple Friedel-Crafts alkylation between a triazine containing tripodal crosslinker 2,4,6-tris[4-(bromomethyl) phenyl]-1,3,5-triazine and dibenzothiophene. Due to surface basicity this porous polymer showed excellent catalytic activity in the heterogeneous multicomponent coupling reaction for the synthesis of 2-amino-4H-chromene derivatives through the reaction between aromatic aldehyde, malononitrile and resorcinol under microwave assisted heating conditions. This triazine-thiophene based porous organic polymer was further sulfonated by using chlorosulfonic acid to obtain sulfonated porous organic polymer STrzDBTH, which showed excellent catalytic activity and recycling efficiency for the synthesis of HMF from carbohydrate based biomass resources. Stepwise functionalization strategy in designing efficient acid/base catalysts via easy polycondensation of organic building blocks presented herein may contribute significantly in heterogeneous organocatalysis in future. coredata.dc:description: Functionalized porous organic polymers are very demanding and promising material in heterogeneous catalysis due to their convenience in synthesis and versatility in framework composition. Further, owing to the tunable porosity, high specific surface area, ease of functionalization and chemical stability, this class of porous polymers have huge potential to be employed both as catalysis and catalyst support. Herein, we report N-rich triazine-thiophene based microporous polymer TrzDBTH through the Friedel-Craft alkylation reaction of tripodal building block 2,4,6-tris[4-(bromomethyl)phenyl]-1,3,5-triazine with dibenzothiophene (DBTH) and used it as a heterogeneous base catalyst for one-pot synthesis of biologically important chromene derivatives. Further, sulfonation to this TrzDBTH material yielded sulfonated hyper-crosslinked porous polymer namely STrzDBTH, which can be used as solid acid catalyst for the synthesis of valuable chemical intermediate 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) from different biomass derived carbohydrates. As a base catalyst, TrzDBTH provides chromene yields from 88 to 93% and its sulfonated derivative STrzDBTH provides the HMF yields from 57 to 97% for different carbohydrate substrates. Both the materials displayed high recycling efficiencies for several catalytic cycles. Thus, these triazine-thiophene based porous organic polymers offer very economical, scalable and recyclable routes for the synthesis chromene derivatives and HMF.
coredata.dc:title: A new triazine-thiophene based porous organic polymer as efficient catalyst for the synthesis of chromenes via multicomponent coupling and catalyst support for facile synthesis of HMF from carbohydrates
